data.title: ACUSON Bonsaiâ¢ Ultrasound System Overview
data.meta_description: This is a short video presentation providing an overview of the ACUSON Bonsaiâ¢ Ultrasound System.
data.text:
This is your acuson Banzai keyboard overview. The right side of the system is where you would find your power cord, your ECG cord, as well as your LAN connector on the left side is where you would have your transducer connections. The system powers up in 28 seconds, 7 seconds from standby. You have a total scan time of 90 minutes with the laptop in an additional 2 hours with the cart. I'm going to be reviewing your workflow group as I draw your attention to the keyboard. You notice this is where you would enter your patient information. The next key would be your proban exam selection. After that you would go into your review key and then the next key is your end exam key. As we move across the top of the keyboard, these are your where your soft keys are located. The soft keys are mode specific and they may have more than one page. The next group of Keys will be your function key. I station is where you can review exams. You have a report key. Your stress echo package your physio key. As well as your eyes own key. If you go to the help key. You notice that you have a keyboard. Next, I want to draw your attention to home base. As you notice, home base has your trackball, you have select keys on your left as well as right side and directly above your trackball you have an update key as well as your measurements package. So directly above home base is where you're going to find your major modes from left to right, you have imode tissue, Doppler pulse wave, continuous wave. Color. Color power as well as your grayscale. You also have your baseline and scale along with depth and focus. From there, you have your overall gain dial as well as your I touch key. I touch is a one touch gain optimization for all modes. Directly below I touch is freeze. Here is where your image capture keys are located. And your user defined keys are located throughout the keyboard and they begin with the letter P An there is a total of 8.
